*This is really important* this girl does not have a 'weird habit' of 
taking contacts out at night. DO take your contacts out at night. It is 
incredibly dangerous to leave contacts in overnight, please do not think 
that most people leave them in, you should take them out. When your eyes 
are closed and you are in deep sleep your eyes roll back into your head. If 
you still have your contacts in then will get stuck behind you eyes, 
causing you to get severe eye infections that could even lead to you 
needing to have an operation or in the worst cases your eye removed. Please 
please please take contacts out at night, do not sleep with them in. No 
hate, this just needs to be said. xxx ﻿

12 is a really good age for having contacts. I am 9 and started wearing 
contacts when I was probably 8. If you wear contact lenses at a younger age 
like 8-9, it would be better. But you need to responsible about your 
lenses. You need to clean them everyday when you take it off. Also, another 
tip, please DO NOT put on your contacts above the sink. My classmate,who 
also wears contacts and introduced contact lenses to me, dropped her 
contact lens in the sink. ANd luckily found it, but it was very dirty. She 
had the wash the contact lenses around 5 times carefully. When I first 
started wearing contact lenses, I was very clumsy and dropped one of my 
contact lenses on the floor. So, I skipped one day of contact lenses. But 
remember, if you didn't put on contact lenses one night, the things you see 
the next day will be blurry. ( I wear contact lenses at night and take them 
off in the morning) Also,contact lenses can make your eyesight better. My 
eyesight was 400 and now it is only 0.25!
Hope the information will help you. Hope your mom will allow you to wear 
contacts

Just so you know, astigmatism has to do with the cornea not being perfectly 
circular shaped. The fact that one eye is worse has nothing to do with 
astigmatism and is actually extremely common. ﻿
top_comment.author: Blackbookproduct10ns

comments.text:
maybe you misunderstood him. astigmatism has to do with an irregularly 
shaped cornea and because of it, the contact lens for astigmatisms are 
slightly weighted at the bottom so that they are oriented correctly. (if 
they aren't correctly oriented everything is blurry and you can actually 
turn it in your eye and see this...if you have astigmatism) with a non 
astigmatism, the orientation does not matter...because of this it is a lot 
more difficult to fit contacts for people with astigmatism. They usually 
have to go back multiple times to get the orientation just right. (this is 
what i had to go through)

top_comment.text:
i never comment on videos but i just wanted to clarify some points so 
everyone would be more informed on contact lens hygeine. I am an optometry 
student and optical dispenser for 5 years. 

the reason why you have different colours for the right and left case is if 
you have different prescriptions for both eyes, it ensures you don't mix up 
the contact lenses. different astigmatism prescription in the eyes may 
require you to do that. (astigmatism is when your eye isn't perfectly round 
but more like a rugby ball shape). people who don't have astigmatism may 
still have different prescriptions in both eyes. so it is good to get in 
the habit to put the right contact lens in the appropriate side of the case.

you SHOULD NOT sleep in your contact lenses unless you are wearing the ones 
that have been approved for such use eg. Airoptix Night and Day. However 
most popular brands do not fall in this category. 

after you put in your contact lenses, you should discard the used solution 
and rinse it with new solution and then allow to air dry rather than doing 
that at the end of the day when you want to take them off.  

I'm also quite surprised your optometrist didn't teach you how to put them 
on and take them off. Here in Australia if you are a first time contact 
lenses wearer it is a must to be taught how to wear and care for your 
contact lens to prevent any infection. 

all that being said, I think it is great that you are doing these videos 
:) ﻿

the method you used to put them in, use the 2nd method you use to take them 
out. Again thank you for the video it was very helpful, I am going to put 
these methods to the test!﻿

comments.text:
+Gracie Glitters You will get them out. The main thing to do when you put 
them in/take them out is to remain calm. Trust me dropping one of your 
contacts is a nightmare. Just be calm, use the method that is most 
comfortable for you to put them in, take them out. You will get it. I have 
wore glasses for over 20 years, it still takes me like 1 minute to get my 
right one in, like 3 minutes to get my left one in, less than 1 minute to 
get them both out. It will take time toi get used to putting them in, 
taking them out.
